Description: Rim, body, and handle sherd of South Ionian pottery little master cup; interior: reserved band at rim, glazed black below; top of lip glazed; exterior: myrtle leaf band with row of added white dots; band at top of handle zone; handle zone reserved; glazed below and on handle root.
Type series: Schlotzhauer little master Ionian Cup type
Curator's comments: Schlotzhauer identifies the sherd a belonging to his group of Ionian little master cups and South Ionian cups with everted rim Type 9B. These cups coincide with Hayes’ Ionian Cup Type XI (Boardman and Hayes 1966, 111-116). Type 9 cups have been found in large numbers in other sanctuary settings including at the Sanctuary of Aphrodite at Miletus, the Sanctuary of Demeter and Kore at Tocra, and at the site of Megara Hyblaea on Sicily. This type was the most common type of South Ionian cups with everted rims found at Naukratis. Hayes suggested a Rhodian origin for these types of cups but this is uncertain (Boardman and Hayes 1966, 114). Schlotzhauer points out that the same myrtle pattern is found on Fikellura style pottery from Miletus and thus suggest a South Ionian or more specifically Milesian origin for the cups (Schlotzhauer 2012, 108-9).
Bibliographic references: Schlotzhauer 2012 / Untersuchungen zur archaischen griechischen Keramik aus Naukratis (p. 52, no. 296)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GE.821) (Phase 3)
